6C2BF63C1CB443509A836F7D529AF84C.description: Move into action if directions are given

239C950D87244475B640919FECED0478.description: Be able to tell the person what was heard or ask a question of the speaker

08D152739118499B885390A62BF1AC71.description: Practice the steps to focused listening

3119786BD01440C9A5AB52241E016F10.description: With support, speak with appropriate volume, enunciation, rate, fluency and expression

018266750FC14E3585B6289FA6656211.description: Describe familiar people, places, things, and events,and withpromptingandsupport,provide additional details.

073080CECD9D4E0FB4EBD71FDB2CF81E.description: Produce complete sentences when appropriate to task and situation, using correct verb tenses to convey a sense of past, present, and future

4171C4546CB14F6FB63919F7138DC461.description: Ask questions to get information, clarify something that is n o t understood, or to gather additional information

84ADD8A9A24740DFABC3290E4F033745.description: Understand and follow up to three step spoken directions

0B301327301842BFB321723BF1F8A603.description: Confirm understanding of information presented orally or through media by restating key elements and asking and answering questions about key details

5BEAE9B1A43C40A18051A1AE779A90BD.description: Demonstrate respect for others and their opinions in discussions

E1B105E9939945709EA91DC0B2315BC6.description: Ask questions to clear up confusion about a topic

58477F99A3BD4FE697C0AA9EF6124229.description: Respond to comments of others through multiple exchanges

7B728195B3194525864C9FAD4E39CF09.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussion such as listening to others, speaking one at a time, and gaining the floor in respectful ways

B4399AD8EAEA4959A8DE994AD2680CB2.description: Initiate and participate in conversations with peers and adults about first grade topics and texts being studied in class

CCB6F155E8F24D9180504AC4BBFF13DC.description:
Speaking and Listening: Comprehension and Collaboration
Students adjust their use of spoken language to communicate effectively with a variety of audiences and for different purposes.

1529B1D287894870A81972D2B22A87DB.description: Form new words through addition, deletion and substitution of sound and letters (e.g., an-man- mat-mast-must-rust-crust)

52214D1076824FF49224B15998700E51.description: Use phonetic spelling for untaught words, drawing on phonemic awareness and spelling conventions

3E479F3A26524172B69959240C292686.description: Use conventional spelling for words with common spelling patterns and for common irregular words

03AEBA1ED24A4C208639C34B7C499E25.description: Use commas in dates and to separate single words in a series

6EDD6C5656154D0094645ED2BA227E31.description: Use end punctuation for sentences, including periods, questions marks, and exclamation points

CBE08F3FA1794A159702C690B53721C5.description: Observe conventions of capitalization, punctuation, and spelling

1910E46EBAF34126AF1FF85766F20D45.description: Identify the subject and predicate in a sentence

EF7DD45BA08242D39D62870C2334F9DC.description: Identify a sentence as having a subject and predicate

822CB84618734624BB44CFF414E513D6.description: Produce and expand complete statements, exclamations and commands in response to prompts and questions. (declarative, interrogative, imperative, and exclamatory- terms not used)

D21EC4BBBE5B4CB7B49EB93DA773C268.description: Understand and use frequently occurring prepositions in English (e.g., during, beyond, toward)

BBB05EEFCCD24822A5F77174F0091418.description: Use verbs to convey a sense of past, present and future in writing and speaking(e.g., YesterdayI walked home;Today I walk home; Tomorrow I will walk home)

6ADDA8BF4B5842BA83FFE85986B47CFC.description: Use subject, object, and possessive pronouns in speaking and writing (e.g., I, me, my, they, them, their)

B3D8172BC7B34BA396E728DE8F7BF69D.description: Use singular and plural nouns with matching verbs in simple sentences (e.g., He hops, we hop)

8551EEAA5C0642658C03065A82D7DDDA.description: Observe conventions of grammar and usage in writing and speaking

D928AE2AC755419FAA94162CA86205EE.description:
Grammar and Usage
Students adjust their use of spoken, written, and visual language (e.g., conventions, style, vocabulary) to communicate effectively with a variety of audiences and for different purposes.

B7DB0BB58BA8456AA9654F911F4CD54B.description:
Draw pictures and write sentences for a specific
reason or audience

2D7BD5F44C964558B3725614EDDCBA25.description: Write for a specific purpose or audience

E5D7DE65B65F47129448FAFF5E8D26FF.description: Use technology to produce writing (with guidance from adults)

AF3CD62DD22C49C0A0059A52DDA2E340.description: Explore his/her voice through the use of personal, high interest vocabulary when writing

3228F60DCC9A4C579FB2521A5C4B93CF.description: Gather information from experience or provided text sources to answer specific questions

A1210B970E1F4CE19DCD0B4B286F9E9B.description: Add details to strengthen writing as needed through revision. (with guidance and support from adults)

C24D76892D8941B3B1F1F7BB176BD59F.description: Write narratives in which they include at least two or more appropriately sequenced events, use time cue words to signal event order, and provide some details and a sense of closure

2D4C828939AC4EC3BC851E8299479F6E.description: Write or draw information about the topic (e.g., My favorite animal is...I like this animal because it...)

13EA01A16FB94A5D947A23383496AF77.description: Write informative and explanatory texts in which the topic is named, supply some facts relevant to the topic, and provide some sense of closure

4431D8FA278B4CF69BC2360A02AD61BB.description: Use words to link opinions and reasons (e.g., because, and, also, therefore)

8983E9BFAC5C4889946CDBB352142720.description: Write opinions in which the topic or book is introduced, state an opinion, and provide a reason for the opinion

BD83D0D43AB648ACAD4327BF30EEFDDB.description: Tell a story that the teacher or other person will write

0B7F08ECF0974056B989F6B7C1187881.description: Discuss ideas to include in a story

809A92C13264462F96BD3E239E71C386.description: Use symbols and drawings to convey information

775C72D9E45F4A45BC6734621EB679D1.description: Distinguish among punctuation marks that can be used to end a sentence (period, question mark, exclamation point)

57C7D528232F4E95B7AB1898265C1B93.description: Spell independently using an understanding of the sounds of the alphabet and knowledge of letter names

2C6DD0D848034E4E937A4D194516D2B3.description: Recognize parts of a sentence (capital letter at the beginning, punctuation at the end)

F0AF68A5A6A34D2890E3A69119783BED.description:
Recognize the months of the year and days of
the week require capitalization

68A11450989B40CA949110CDD5B6068B.description: Recognize the pronoun “I” should be capitalized

7B7D2C5F12A34EA7836593C837DE4CB3.description: Print all capital letters and lower case letter of the alphabet

A0CED57102564DC487EA6E53D3B35AB2.description: Demonstrate proper spacing between letters and words

5CE80A24948F41CBA7ED5715A2E0A5D2.description: Use uppercase letters in the beginning of names and sentences.

4C61A03D8C70479989A316914AD5E8A5.description: Write first and last name using upper and lower case letters

B9B64229C3174833824B1AC6440726F7.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the organization and basic features and conventions of print

1D4D901C110D46DCAC6AEA545807A773.description: Mark answers (underline, draw a line across).

F48E80E20D814646AF00BA9746A8411A.description:
Correct manuscript letter formation and
maintain correct handwriting position.

71A1B8AB83C348D3B49AE02C0F1DE351.description: Work from left to write, top to bottom.

4E2E48B542BA49A590FD6E1167CEFEAD.description: Use the conventions of print such as the following in purposeful writing activities

E795074EF55B4B0EB48C8CB94787FE5D.description:
Writing – Processes and Features
Students employ a wide range of strategies as they write and use different writing process elements appropriately to communicate with different audiences for a variety of purposes.

E2FAB655571A47DC9A2D7CF0DD54A985.description: Apply Catholic values and teachings in the evaluation of literary themes and plots.

CA22E8387E9842A3B66BEF48525BFEBA.description: Read and follow written directions for grade level materials

E78F100E6C6B4810922378CE0E0B40A2.description: Interpret written directions for grade level materials

B3EBDB61C10F4E3D8F4AB5EB5A885E51.description: Read signs and symbols used across curriculum content areas(e.g.,maps,temperature,and charts)

3B9FC7958A1A4C47BADAB645E5DBF4C0.description: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, reading as necessary

F09CC48C7B8D4C628D7D902E70104B2D.description: Read on-level text orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression on successive readings

19C06E8D65224DF98A93BFD85110CEBC.description: Read on-level text with purpose and understanding

0CCBD50BDAE242F482EE8C2D61D5125D.description: Read grade appropriate text with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension

F566C6844EC044FDBCC7FBFAA2D95ECB.description: Identify various genre (e.g., fairytales, folktales, poems, historical fiction, narratives, biography, non-fiction, Psalms, Gospels, Biblical stories - parables

39F045F41D574AD79177EAE0AB789FE1.description: Distinguish between various types of literary genre

F7650709FDF94423B6F84F73D61F3FED.description: Compare and contrast personal knowledge and experience with events or characters within a story or text (text to self-connection)

7888ADA207604E9597E7824368111228.description: Draw a picture to depict sequence after listening to or reading a story

B6F41798AEDC497285840EFB8E922B3D.description: Recognize cause and effect, explain why specific effect occurred based on context

E08861DD7866415690DD3591319EBA55.description: Identify main idea, theme and supporting details

3F77EB6371224BD785F120DEE82D2FCB.description: Make predictions based on the title of the book or about what will happen next

218D1DE5208F41A6BBB6E708AEDA0127.description: Identify key words to draw conclusions

2CFBDAE3A35940F499BD577FAF83B587.description: Discuss a book or story read aloud

B0F59E00BB4541CDB1D439185CCF23A3.description: Identify words and phrases in stories or poems that suggest feelings or appeal to the senses

A4F397C210F04F57A8736C92669F37AB.description: Communicate thoughts, feelings, judgments, understanding, personal experiences and attitudes, draw conclusions and make predictions after reading or listening to material of grade level text

020827A45B8A4F6585FACFF0D6F8884E.description: Compare and contrast two or more versions of the same story (e.g., Cinderella stories, Gospel stories) by different authors or from different cultures. (text to text connection)

4A8D18EB9E254C1AAFEF3E4595B656BA.description: Recognize basic similarities and differences between two texts on the same topic (e.g., in illustrations or descriptions)

3B5CDFB05F684F2097D9252D1B8404F5.description: Compare and contrast the adventures of characters in familiar stories.

0192379471C3485980FAA2DFA328913F.description: Choose age and ability appropriate material for a variety of reading purposes (“just right” books, I P.I.C.K – Daily 5)

63F5F5982D7046E09BA00482B01D556F.description: Determine the author’s purpose for writing

9EB13803DDEE42BF959E0D8423F9752F.description: Identify a purpose for reading and appreciate various forms of literature

E0D96533E76C4A4B9D450FB3213BAA81.description: Begin to use context to understand word and sentence meaning

A7BEF75A50F9489AB32B8432969D2DFF.description: Use context to understand word and sentence meaning after listening to or reading text

BC473AAA4B2B403C827A10A8CEBF4DEC.description: Use context to understand word and sentence meaning

9D014B3E35BB451A877E07CC6829F83A.description: Sequence and retell events/parts of a story

6644C20D2A834050BF3F761005BD3615.description: Use pictures, illustrations, text and detail in a text to describe the main idea

36309323ADC744D48C4C6BD5D43FB5AE.description: Use pictures, illustrations, text and detail in a story to describe characters, events or settings

3C9E2CCE8B10479B97F0351296501AF8.description: Use picture clues, word chunks, word patterns, structural clues and context clues to understand text

525E6230906647039EB6FA01A7483A04.description:
Reading Literature and Informational Text - Comprehension, Response, and Analysis
Students read a wide range of print and non-print texts to build an understanding of texts, of themselves, and of the cultures of the United States and the world; to acquire new information; to respond to the needs and demands of society and the workplace; and for personal fulfillment. Among these texts are fiction and nonfiction, classic and contemporary works, and literature from many periods.

7DE1237B381A4D80839B605DF8C8A6E0.description: Use table of contents, captions, headings, glossary, index to locate key facts or information

B5EDAC46489C4E05A4DEC1C8F41936F4.description: Know and use various text features

4360F0ABA01241B9A2564EBDE771CA44.description: Identify the main characters in a story

1EA092F126BD43F99F9133D0C444D45F.description: Identify who is speaking at various points in a text

21F9127C8F504DE09C51D6E2E8C2AA6E.description: Describe how a text groups information into general categories (e.g., cows, pigs, and horses are farm animals)

6C5D7BD7572444B2A3197CA2257672D9.description: Classify words based on stated characteristics in informational texts

794033DF7034479BAD68274606646A79.description: Describe how objects and words are grouped into general categories (e.g., desk, chair, sofa: furniture, short vowel, long vowel...)

A4B58A38BE2E433FA0E824E57C1FE33C.description: Classify objects and words according to use and categories

7D0F8A55B1304D3DA7F0221DF20BAA00.description: Use title page, table of contents, to locate information

33B6DD304B304754B5699F12A3A11063.description:
Llocate the title, author and illustrator of a text
and define the role of each

E5C9B033D1F2408A8577FF450CECF3FE.description: Understand the difference between narrative stories and poems

494B5CFCDC7F428DB496DB4E8836161B.description: Distinguish between fiction and non- fiction

A102DEFD4A7241A492C6685F87FB6757.description: Recognize common genres of texts (e.g. storybooks, bible stories, poems, fiction, non- fiction)

AA05E335FA9249D08FA93D53D99F861D.description: Identify words and phrases in stories or poems that suggest feelings or appeal to the senses

BA5BB8A3E79C47229F8EA17F4238339D.description: Demonstrate alphabetical order by locating words in the dictionary or glossary

82F582467D2B4C8AB8F99E26DD3E170C.description: Recognize that the dictionary is organized in alphabetical order

99D19451E6234F39A524CF4F672EA89D.description: Identify distinguishing features of text (i.e. labels, captions, diagrams, illustrations)

91C71BE43A0640E1884E450C0C4EC27C.description: Locate the parts of a book including: title page, table of contents, author, illustrator, and glossary

C97355D57D044AC9A923E722DFE56349.description: Demonstrate understanding of the organization and basic features of print

BF4C4E8D5B814905B0DDBD8B65E153D5.description: Ask questions about unknown words in a text

3D42620A3B654EE1A31F017399625C49.description:
Reading Literature and Informational Texts - Craft and Structure
Students apply knowledge of language structure, language conventions (e.g., spelling and punctuation), media techniques, figurative language, and genre to create, critique, and discuss print and non-print texts.

6638528C6BE14FB2908109112F73BDD5.description: Use new vocabulary in discussion and daily application

AB8EE5BF259F46CAA8348BFB7B28CC2B.description: Use newly learned words acquired through conversations,reading and responding to texts

130AA3908CEE40FEAF48BEF2323A3850.description: Demonstrate understanding of the concept of multiple-meaning words (e.g. match, kind, play) by identifying meanings of some grade- appropriate examples of such words

0EC41B51AAEA4C98AF11726FE21E6B70.description: Define words by category and by one or more key attributes (e.g., duck is a bird that swims, a tiger is a large cat with stripes)

F3DDA2942873427D9CF2BBF148B6E696.description: Use common affixes in English as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word

753425F57535491CA60C6CA5F7F59924.description: Use sentence-level context as a clue to meaning of an unknown word

1B489216C4DA48BE9A049FFF88F9EDB8.description: Sort words into categories (e.g., colors, clothing) to gain a sense of the concepts the categories represent.

5F7403136D5C4A9CB8A2D1C8EA48209A.description: Determine word meanings (based on first grade reading)

E7AFB8A56A1F41D5BA4A7B3EFFBDD34E.description: Identify and use common homonyms and synonyms

0431C5B55AC8486D8BE6AB0F88B9672A.description: Distinguish shades of meaning among verbs differing in manner (e.g., look, glance, stare, glare, scowl) and adjectives differing in intensity (e.g., large, gigantic) by defining, choosing, or acting out the meanings

F7E6E0034F0043AD9D14AA236DD492AD.description: Build real-life connections between words and their use (e.g., note a place at home that is cozy)

9AA992F3A2F642A68540B450137BBDD7.description: Demonstrate understanding of spoken words, d syllables, and phonemes.

2F7FE3AF06174A23867CA534B59E0FD5.description: Understand word relationships and phonological awareness

A89E716FA5FF4123BFBCDF0EB54AC432.description: Recognize contractions and associate the two words that make up the contraction

26350306A316456C875DA724F9EE2389.description: Know the sound correspondence for hard and soft/c/and/g/

4952AF0D797245CAAEC874F4D9871A75.description: Associate the sound of “Y” when it is used as a vowel with either the long /e/ or long /i/

9B2C3C61071049319FE87ED172FC3BC3.description:
Associate the various families of blends with
the sounds they represent (e.g., R-S-L)

8A2625A4FF494B7E882EA793D7D17145.description: Read at least 100 high frequency words by sight

DB9F69611655407A896E46A319A88E9A.description: Recognize and read grade-appropriate irregularly spelled words (e.g., said, were, could,would, their,there,through,none, both)

DCC0BBB41E36408DBAB87B41F47F2AA7.description: Read words with inflectional endings (e.g.,- s,- es, -ing, -er, -est)

B75C6AA7791C48BBA79576330E04D028.description: Orally produce single-syllable words by blending phonemes, including consonant blends (e.g./cats/, /black/blast/)

14FECE8BC1AC4CA29933013C64D58499.description: Aurally distinguish long from short vowel sounds in spoken single-syllable words. (e.g./tap/vs./tape/, /sock/vs./soak/, /sit/vs./sightA

BFB065CACB2F443B9C8D0D51D6AE1955.description: Decode two syllable words following basic patterns (e.g., rabbits) by breaking the words intosyllables

DA333CC782194704A44467A32B98A488.description: Use knowledge that every syllable must have a vowel sound to determine the number of syllables in a printed word

47CC659E3FBA4B81AA9E39FE864ABEFE.description: Know final –e (e.g. take, side) and common vowel team conventions (e.g., rain, day, week, seat, road, show) for representing long vowels

9D3E0A2341284EEA860228D24B7150A9.description: Decode regularly spelled one-syllable words (e.g., lock, much, see, rain, slide, bake)

7EDD1C6F8AE142D189F51B6EBD8BF398.description: Isolate and pronounce initial, medial vowel, and final phonemes in spoken single-syllable words.(e.g.fast,fast, fast)

D289AF91DBF24CDD892F509C545CA30B.description: Add or subtract individual phonemes in simple, one-syllable words to make new words(e.g.,/at/-/sat/-/ mat/-/map/)

D8B76D646A7146E389049D2D3E83DC59.description: Segment spoken single-syllable words into their complete sequence of individual phonemes (e.g., lap: /l/-/a/-/p/--/ f/-/l/-/a/-/p/)

4833D3727A734DA9B8794F3F6153C4BA.description: Know the spelling-sound correspondence for common consonant digraphs (e.g., ck, wr, tr, th, sh)

9E937CCEFEB64D9AB5F92897EF637357.description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills in decoding words

B27DF98AED6C41EF89D3AF95B66E1446.description:
Vocabulary Development and Word Analysis
Students apply a wide range of strategies to comprehend, interpret, evaluate, and appreciate texts. They draw on their prior experience, their interactions with other readers and writers, their knowledge of word meaning and of other texts, their word identification strategies and understanding textual features (e.g. sound-letter correspondence, sentence structure, context, graphics).
